Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp with a heart-shaped nozzle, decorated on the discus with a frieze of three hounds chasing a hare, interrupted by the nozzle-channel. The shoulder is decorated with ovules (largely obscured). The oil-lamp stands on a raised base. Covered with an brown-grey slip, probably over-fired and intended to be orange-red. Brown Nile silt with grey core.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Unprovenanced parallels in the British Museum (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, nos Q2011-Q2017), copying Loeschcke Type VIII. Q2012 is probably from same mould series. Loeschcke, S. 1919. Lampen aus Vindonissa. Zϋrich.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.18) (Phase 3)
